comments:
1) open a file and make it dirty
2) open another file not in the same project
3) delete project of first file
4) shutdown eclipse
5) restart eclipse
6) press on the editor tab for the first file

Having looked into this, I don't see a way editor implementors that do not have 
a custom editor input to achieve that the editor is not remembered. This would 
be the prefered solution, as the user explicily chose to not save the editor. 
Moving to Platform UI.

Eclipse 20021203

Tried the following four scenarios
1/ when deleting the project, select 'do not delete contents'
   do not save file when prompted

2/ when deleting the project, select 'also delete contents ...'
   do not save file when prompted

3/ when deleting project, select 'do not delete contents'
   save the file when prompted

4/ when deleting project, select 'also delete contents ...'
   save the file when prompted.

As you would expect there is no errors/logs generated for 3/ and 4/
For both 1/ and 2/ a log is generated, but no NPE.  The log is:

This seems reasonable to me.
